Award.AwardTitle: ABI Sustaining: A visualization and analysis resource for comparative microbial ecology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Marine Biological Laboratory is awarded a grant for sustaining operation of the web service VAMPS (Visualization and Analysis of Microbial Population Structures, http://vamps.mbl.edu). VAMPS is a free, open-source database-driven website that allows researchers using data from massively-parallel sequencing (MPS, or ?next-generation sequencing?) projects to analyze the diversity of microbial communities and the relationships between communities, to explore these analyses in an intuitive visual context, and to download analyses and images for publication. VAMPS currently hosts more than 200 projects encompassing more than 5000 datasets and over 250 million sequence tags, and is used by nearly 900 investigators from around the world. The rapid expansion of MPS technologies with the concurrent drastic drop in sequencing costs has revolutionized molecular microbial ecology by making the detailed analysis of complex communities over time and space a tractable research pursuit for small research groups. The ability to generate 104?107 reads with relative ease brings with it many downstream complications. Beyond the computational resources and skills needed to analyze data, it is difficult to compare datasets, which may represent spatial or temporal community gradients, changes to a community in response to nutrients or stress, the response of a biota to its host, or other relationships, in an intuitive and interactive manner that leads to hypothesis generation. VAMPS was developed to address these challenges and to facilitate research by individuals or collaborating groups working on projects of any scale. Sequence data and associated metadata can be uploaded directly to VAMPS by users or by sending data to the VAMPS project team; MPS reads can be automatically quality filtered and assigned to both taxonomic structures and to taxonomic-independent clusters. These can then be linked to metadata and compared using a wide variety of analytical and visualization tools. Each result is extensively hyperlinked to other analysis and visualization options, promoting data exploration and leading to a greater understanding of data relationships. A major strength of VAMPS is that researchers can compare not only datasets within their own projects but can compare these with datasets from projects such as NSF-funded Long Term Ecological Research projects, the International Census of Marine Microbes, the Human Microbiome Project, and hundreds of other individual projects.

While the advent of MPS methods has allowed microbial ecologists to ask meaningful questions with ever-greater precision, it brings significant challenges to individual small laboratories struggling to manage megabytes or even gigabytes of data. VAMPS obviates the need for individual research groups to make the considerable investment in computational infrastructure and bioinformatic support otherwise necessary to process, analyze, and interpret MPS data for microbial ecology. Any web-capable device can be used to upload, process, explore, and extract data and results from VAMPS, and the VAMPS development team is available to assist in all aspects of data processing and analysis. VAMPS encourages researchers to share sequence and metadata, and fosters collaboration between researchers of disparate biomes who recognize common patterns in shared data. VAMPS has been used in more than 50 publication and at least 13 NSF-funded projects. VAMPS provides unique educational opportunities through its combination of data from a variety of environments, its integration of sequence cluster-based and taxonomy-based analytical and visualization tools, and the instruction provided by project developers. In addition to uncounted students among its registered users, the VAMPS website is used by graduate students in the Brown-MBL IGERT Reverse Ecology: Computational Integration of Genomes, Organisms and Environments; in the MBL's graduate/postdoctoral level Microbial Diversity summer course, and in the MBL Special Topics course Strategies and Techniques for Analysis of Microbial Population Structures, which draws graduate students, postdocs and principle investigators from around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sustained the web service VAMPS (Visualization and Analysis of Microbial Population Structures, http://vamps.mbl.edu).  VAMPS is a free, open-source database-driven website that allows researchers using massively-parallel sequencing data (MPS, or “next-generation sequencing”) to analyze the diversity of microbial communities and the relationships between communities, to explore these analyses in an intuitive visual context, and to download analyses and images for publication.

Intellectual Merit:  The rapid expansion of MPS technologies with the concurrent drastic drop in sequencing costs has revolutionized molecular microbial ecology by making the detailed analysis of complex communities over time and space a tractable research pursuit for small research groups.  However, the ability to generate 104–107 reads with relative ease brings with it many downstream complications.  Beyond the computational resources and skills needed to analyze data, it is difficult to compare datasets, which may represent spatial or temporal community gradients, changes to a community in response to nutrients or stress, the response of a biota to its host, or other relationships, in an intuitive and interactive manner that leads to hypothesis generation. VAMPS addresses these challenges and facilitates research by individuals or collaborating groups working on projects of any scale.  Sequence data and associated metadata can be uploaded directly to VAMPS or by sending data to VAMPS staff; MPS reads can be automatically quality filtered and assigned to both taxonomic structures and to taxonomic-independent clusters.  These can then be linked to metadata and compared using a wide variety of analytical and visualization tools.  Each result is extensively hyperlinked to other analysis and visualization options, promoting data exploration and leading to a greater understanding of data relationships.  A major strength of VAMPS is that researchers can compare not only datasets within their own projects but can compare these with datasets from NSF-funded Long Term Ecological Research projects, the International Census of Marine Microbes, the Deep Life Project, the Human Microbiome Project, and more than 1,000 other individual projects and more than 70,000 individual datasets.

Broader Impacts:  While the advent of MPS methods has allowed microbial ecologists to ask meaningful questions with ever-greater precision, it brings significant challenges to individual small laboratories struggling to manage gigabytes of data.  VAMPS obviates the need for individual research groups to make the considerable investment in computational infrastructure and bioinformatic support otherwise necessary to process, analyze, and interpret MPS data for microbial ecology.  Any web-capable device can be used to upload, process, explore, and extract data and results from VAMPS.  VAMPS encourages researchers to share sequence and metadata, and fosters collaboration between researchers of disparate biomes who recognize common patterns in shared data.  VAMPS provides unique educational opportunities through its combination of data from a variety of environments and its integration of cluster- and taxonomy-based analytical and visualization tools.  In addition to uncounted students among its registered users, the VAMPS website is used in the MBL’s graduate/postdoctoral level Microbial Diversity and Strategies and Techniques for Analysis of Microbial Population Structures summer courses which draw graduate students, postdocs and principle investigators from around the world, and in undergraduate courses taught by MBL and University of Chicago faculty.

Outcomes:  Project activities were divided into three parts: assisting users with data uploads, data processing, and analysis; routine maintenance of the existing VAMPSv1 website and codebase, including refining the backend database to eliminate redundancy and increase query speed; and developing the new VAMPS2.0 website (https://vamps2.mbl.edu).  An important aspect of the VAMPS2.0 design is that the code is stored on a public site (https://github.com/avoorhis/vamps-node.js) so that anyone is able to recreate the entire VAMPS2.0 website or install individual programs units or plugins.  Instructions are included. 

We developed a new application for VAMPS2 that allows users to retrieve reproducible images and data from the site using custom scripts or Jupyter Notebooks.  This feature is a partial response to NSF Dear Colleague Letter NSF 17-022, "Encouraging reproducibility in computing and communications research." and was developed in part through our integration of VAMPS with the Marine Biolodiversity Virtual Laboratory (MBVL) under NSF CCF 1539291.

We also enhanced metadata applications by improving ontology requirements in collaboration with the Census of Deep Life project, The Environmental Ontology project (EnvO) and the Gazetteer project (Gaz).  Project owners and designated assistants can add and edit metadata using these well-defined ontologies.

The original VAMPS1.0 webservice has 2,895 registered users and houses 42,208 datasets in 1,151 projects and a total of 598,376,183 unique sequences.  There were 1842 new users during the project period, and 30,549 new datasets.  Since it's rollout in the summer of 2016 VAMPS2.0 has registered 495 users (437 since the third year report) and maintains 29,723 datasets in 688 projects and a total of 252,419,552.  These are new data not represented in VAMPS1.0.
